column22: SubQuestions
column23: O metodo se baseia em uma combinação de analise de dependências que analisa a questão sintaticamente complexa e responde a questão usando tupla com asserções com um numero de argumentos.  Eles aprensentam 4 módulos principais:  (1) Question Paraphrasing: onde é feita a rescrita a pergunta original em um conjunto de templates. Para isso, eles usam o e WikiAnswers paraphrasing templates dataset, que já contém 5 milhões de templates. Porém, como o dataset é cheio de ruídos eles criaram uma regressa de associação entre os templates do dataset para verificar se os templates estão corretos ou não. (2) Question Parsing: onde são criadas as n-tuplas lógicas na query da etapa anterior usando análise de denpendencia. Nessa etapa eles usam árvore de dependência e analisam a relação entre as entidades da frase para criar as tuplas. (3) Open KB Querying: Etapa em que eles testam cada tupla dentro do KG para gerar uma lista de respostas candidatas. Nesse processos, eles utilizam um conjunto de assertions indexadas no SOLR e, na proxima etapa, fazem um alinhamento entre tupla e o KG para encontrar os relacionamentos (Usam POStag e outros NLP tools para isso) (4) Answer Ranking: Validamento e ranqueamento dos candidatos a resposta. Para isso usam um conjunto de análises de similaridade, n_gran e frequencia das entidades em cada resposta. Por último, fazendo um log-linear para calcular a probabilidade da resposta correta ser aquela.

column23: We begin by identifying entities from the KB that are mentioned in the question and we match a set of query templates to the question. The final result of this step is a set of all the matched query candidates. We now have a set of query candidates, where each candidate is enriched with information about which of its entities and relations match which parts of the question how well. It remains to rank the candidates in order to find the best matching candidate.

QUINT accomplishes this by i) automatically decomposing the question into its constituent clauses"Utiliza árvore de analise de dependência principalmente para lidar com enunciados composicionais", ii) computing answers for each constituent using our templates, and iii) combining these answers to obtain the final answer.

column27: A detailed analysis of the results on the WebQuestions test set reveals that of the 2032 test questions, 3 could not be matched to any of our templates. Another 33 test questions were matched to a template, but no query candidates were generated. The first cause of this issue is the incompleteness of our predicate lexicon, resulting in empty lookups. This suggests that we can benefit from extending our lexicon construction scheme. The second cause is incorrect dependency parse trees and POS tag annotations.

column22: A Memory Network model that operates a symbolic memory structured as (key, value) pairs.
column23: one defines a memory, which is a possibly very large array of slots which can encode both long-term and short-term context. At test time one is given a query, which is used to iteratively address and read from the memory  looking for relevant information to answer the question. At each step, the collected information from the memory is cumulatively added to the original query to build context for the next round. At the last iteration, the final retrieved context and the most recent query are combined as features to predict a response from a list of candidates.

column22: (1) entity linking, which links n-grams in questions to KB entities, and (2) relation detection, which identifies the KB relation(s) a question refers to
column23: Entity Re-Ranking (first-step relation detection): Use the raw question text as input for a relation detector to score all relations in the KB that are associated to the entities in ELK(q); use the relation scores to re-rank ELK(q) and generate a shorter list EL0 K0 (q) containing the top-K0 entity candidates 2 Relation Detection: Detect relation(s) using the reformatted question text in which the topic entity is replaced by a special token <e> 3 Query Generation: Combine the scores from step 1 and 2, and select the top pair (ˆe, rˆ) (Section 5.3) 4 Constraint Detection (optional): Compute similarity between q and any neighbor entity c of the entities along rˆ (connecting by a relation rc) , add the high scoring c and rc to the query.

column14: Question analysis phase: This processing involves a syntactic and a semantic analysis. In this phase we find how the terms in the question relate to each other and make a hypothesis about the correspondence. Mapping phase: Based on the Linked Data consisting of subject-property-object (SPO) triples, each NL question firstly is transformed into a triple-based representation (Query Triple). Then, the corresponding resources in the KB are mapped for the phrases in the query triples. Disambiguation phase: In the disambiguation task, we determine which of the resources identified during the phrase mapping task are the right ones. Query construction phase: This component creates the final SPARQL query using information provided by above tree steps i.e. and using both question features extracted from question analysis phase and semantic information from KB.

column13: We use syntax dependency tree to syntactically analyze complex questions, and then obtain the final answer by subgraph matching in the knowledge base. Through generating a syntactic dependency tree, we can break a complex question into some simple questions to answer.
column14: (1) We also need to find the entity in the question first, and then (2)backtrack to the root node according to the position of the entity in the syntax dependent tree until the child node of a node has “的” or it is a predicate, then the backtracking is stopped. (3)Take these nodes and their children as a sub-branch. (4) Answer this sub-branch as a simple question, replace this branch with the answer, and make a second round of answer. If the remaining syntax tree is an empty set after removing the stop word and the wh-word, the problem is treated as a simple question, and only one round of processing is enough.

column3: TEQUILA: Temporal question answering over knowledge bases
column4: Jia, Z. / Abujabal, A. / Roy, R.S. / Str tgen, J. / Weikum, G.
column5: Zheng Jia / Abdalghani Abujabal / Rishiraj Saha Roy / Jannik Str Tgen / Gerhard Weikum
column10: International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management, Proceedings
column18: https://qa.mpi-inf.mpg.de/tequila/tequila.zip, and a demo is available at https://gate.d5.mpi-inf.mpg.de/tequila/
column22: TEQUILA, is built on a rule-based framework that encompasses four stages of processing: (i) detecting temporal questions, (ii) decomposing questions and rewriting sub-questions, (iii) retrieving candidate answers for sub-questions, and (iv) temporal reasoning to combine and reconcile the results of the previous stage into final answers. For stage (iii), we leverage existing KB-QA systems, that are geared for answering simple questions.
column23: TEQUILA has four stages. It detects if a question has temporal intent. It decomposes and rewrites the question into non-temporal sub-questions and temporal constraints. Answers to sub-questions are then retrieved from the underlying KB-QA engine. Finally, TEQUILA uses constraint reasoning on temporal intervals to compute final answers to the full question.

column2: TEQUILA fails yields insights towards future work: (i) Decomposition and rewriting were incorrect (for example, in “where did the pilgrims come from before landing in america?”, ‘landing’ is incorrectly labeled as a noun, triggering case 3 instead of case 1 in Table 1); (ii) The correct temporal predicate was not found due to limitations of the similarity function; and (iii) The temporal constraint or the time scope to use during reasoning was wrongly identified.

column3: An Interpretable Reasoning Network for Multi-Relation Question Answering
column4: Zhou, Mantong / Huang, Minlie / Zhu, Xiaoyan
column5: Mantong Zhou / Minlie Huang / Xiaoyan Zhu
column10: Proceedings of the 27th International Conference on Computational Linguistics
column22: Reasoning Network that employs an interpretable, hop-by-hop reasoning process for question answering.
column23: The reasoning network has three modules: input module, reasoning module, and answer module. The input module encodes a question to a vector representation and updates the representation of the question at each hop of the reasoning process. The reasoning module aims to attend to a particular part of the question at each hop, predict an associated relation in knowledge base, and then update its state. The answer module chooses the corresponding entity from KB at each hop. At the last hop, the selected entity is chosen as the final answer.

column3: Answering complex questions by joining multi-document evidence with quasi knowledge graphs
column4: Lu, X. / Abujabal, A. / Pramanik, S. / Wang, Y. / Roy, R.S. / Weikum, G.
column5: Xiaolu Lu / Abdalghani Abujabal / Soumajit Pramanik / Yafang Wang / Rishiraj Saha Roy / Gerhard Weikum
column10: SIGIR 2019 - Proceedings of the 42nd International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval
column16: QUEST (QUEstion answering with Steiner Trees) first constructs an ad hoc, noisy knowledge graph by dynamically retrieving question-relevant text documents and running Open Information Extraction on them to produce triple subject-predicate-object
column22: Cornerstones. To find answers in the quasi KG, we first identify pivotal nodes that we call cornerstones: every node that matches a word or phrase in the question, with similarity above a threshold, becomes a cornerstone. Also, relation nodes and type nodes become cornerstones. All cornerstone nodes for our running example question have thick borders. These nodes are weighted based on the matching or similarity scores. The key idea for identifying answer candidates is that these nodes should be tightly connected to many cornerstones. To formalize this intuition, we consider three factors: (i) answers lie on paths connecting cornerstones, (ii) short paths are preferred, and (iii) paths with higher weights are better
column23: QUEST processes questions in two phases: on-the-fly construction of the quasi KG for the question, and, the graph algorithm for computing ranked answers. Together, these phases comprise the following five steps: (1a) Retrieving question-relevant documents from an open corpus (e.g., the entire Web), (1b) Extracting proximity-based SPO triples from these documents using Open IE techniques, (1c) Building a noisy quasi KG from these triples, (2a) Computing GSTs on the quasi KG to derive candidate answers, (2b) Filtering and scoring candidates to produce ranked answers

column23: The CIPITR framework reads a natural language query and writes a program as a sequence of actions, guided at every step by constraints posed by the KB and the answer-type. Additionally, further improvements are required to induce complex programs without availability of gold program input variables

column23: (1) question interpretation: (1.1) Parsing:  Geram os tokens usando um ML supervisionado. Question type detection is implemented as a bi-LSTM e We use another biLSTM+CRF neural network for extracting references to entities, classes and predicates. Em ambos, usam o GLOVE como wordvector e Common Crawl corpus with 840B tokens and 300 dimensions. (1.2) Matching:  Retornam uma lista de candidatos com o maior valor de similaridade com os tokens aprendidos e as entidades/relações no KG. Nessa etapa usam o Fasttext para representação das palavras e   ElasticSearch (Lucene)  (2) answer inference.: (2.1)Subgraph extraction: Extrair triples in the KG that contain at least one entity. As entidades extraídas são passadas como seeds para a próxima etapa (matriz de adjacencia) (2.2)Message passing:  é feito em 3 etapas  (1) property update, (2) entity update, and (3) score aggregation. Basicamente seleciona os nós adjacentes e propaga a confianca wise-element multipl, soma e normaliza os pesos e por fim faz a ativação do nó. (Basicamente, é uma NN fazendo foward activation)
column27: QAmp is not without limitations. It is designed to handle questions where the answer is a  subset of entities or an aggregate based on this subset, e.g., questions for which the expected answer is a subset of properties in the graph, are currently out of scope. An important next step is to use QAmp to improve the recall of the benchmark dataset by complementing the answer set with missing answers derived from relaxing the dataset  ssumptions. Recognizing relation directionality is an important direction for future work, which requires extending existing benchmark datasets and the addition of more cases  here an explicit order is required to retrieve correct answers. Another direction is to  mprove predicate matching, which is the weakest component of the proposed approach as identified in our ablation study. Finally, unsupervised message passing can be  dopted for other tasks that require uncertain reasoning on KGs, such as knowledge base completion, text entailment, summarization, and dialogue response generation

column23: Etapa offline: (1)  Collect query structures: Descobrem as estruturas equivalentes entres as querys de treino e extraem as principais estuturas das queries (2) Collect frequent query substructures: Decompem cada query e pegam todas as subqueries. (3)  Train query substructure predictors: Trinam uma NN para calcular a probabilidade de cada substrutura pertencer a a aquery original. Etapa online: (1)Predict query substructures: Calculam a probabilidade de uma query definida na etapa offlinie-3. (2) Rank existing query structures: Fazem o ranqueamento das estruturas para saber a mais apropriada para responder a pergunta (3)Merge query substructures:  Fazem o merge das queries para responder as perguntas (4) Grounding and validation: Usam um NED para extrair as entendiades para criar a query executavel em um KB. Para cada query gerada, eles tentam todas as possabilidades de entity linking resultantens do NER e usam um validador de gramática para checar se o doman/rang estçao corretos.

Salvam esses dados em uma tupla de "constraints".Depois de retiraram essa lista, decompoem a query q restante em várias sub queries usando padrões manuais ou outras regras semânticas. Depois de geraram as subqueries, eles fazem uma simlariadade entre as subqqueries e o dicionário criado na etapa (1)offline, usando probabilinadade de Modelo de linguagem(n-Gram) e word-embeddings. (2)Complete query graph generation: Geração de todas as possiveis combinação de grafos completos baseado nos subgrafos que satisfazem simlaridade da etapa anterior >0.6 trocando as entidades pelo <E> usando co-reference resllution. (3) Ranking and answer generation: Ranqueamento de todos os grafos da etapa anterior atraves da funcao de associação. No final, usam uma rando forest para utilizar a tecninca "learning-to-rank".

column16: Stepwise Reasoning Network. In this model, multi-relation question answering is formulated as a sequential decision problem. Given a natural language question, SRN learns a policy which starts from the topic entity, and performs effective path search over the KG to obtain the answer. Specifically, conditioned on the question and previous decisions, SRN leverages beam search to take a list of triples at each step

column27: Following some existing embedding-based methods, SRN employs  multi-hop reasoning to answer multi-relation questions. From a  certain point of view, multi-hop reasoning is similar to semantic  parsing, since both of them are focus on detecting correct paths from  topic entities to answer nodes, and the paths generated by multihop reasoning can also form logic forms. However, when faced with  more complex questions like “Which player is the highest in NBA?”,  multi-hop reasoning cannot handle them very well, because there  exist constraints requiring to be attached to the paths between topic  entities and candidate answers.  Ou seja problema com peguntas que não tem a entidade explicita no texto

column23: Firstly, in the offline stage, the underlying KG is encoded into a low-dimensional embedding space based on generalized local knowledge graphs which represent the contexts of vertices/edges. Then, in the online stage, each entity/relation phrase of the given NLQ is mapped to a set of candidate matching vertices/edges of the underlying KG. With the embedding vectors learned in the offline stage, the mapping results are utilized to compute the structure of the target query. Finally, we select the most suitable matching vertices/edges and assemble them into the target query according to the computed query structure
